body.p: To his Excellency Thomas E Bramlette, Governor of Kentucky --

Your petitioner William Lowry would respectfully show unto your Excellency that he was convicted by a Jury of Laurel County Ky. at its August term 1864 upon a charge of felony for horse stealing, and sentenced to the Penitentiary for the term of four years

He states that he is about twenty one years of age, and a member of Captain Burroughs company when he resigned, and Roland was appointed his captain, and belonged to Col Frank Wolfords old regiment, and has been in the service from the formation of said regiment until the present difficulty He states he was on his road home in company with others, and his horse was tired and unable to go farther, that he did take a horse in the day time and time left his; He did not take the horse with any felonious intent He was going through the mountains, where there was danger of being overtaken by rebels, and thought if he was left alone, he would, in all probability be captured or bushwhacked --

Your petitioner states that he was and is a perfect stranger in Laurel County, and was out of money, and of course had no chance for defence on the trial, or at least a very bad chance to show his innocence

Your petitioner will say to your Excellency that he
has been a faithful soldier all the time

He is an obscure boy, and has always demeaned himself as an honest man, and was never before accused of dishonesty, or before a Court of Justice on any charge whatever -- Your petitioner therefore asks your Excellency to pardon him, and let him go into the service of his country And if your Excellency will not pardon him upon any other grounds he here proposes to volunteer in the army and help up wind up the war
Your petitioner hopes that under all the facts and circumstances in the case, Your Excellency will pardon him
We whose names are hereto annexed, from our knowledge of the petitioner would most respectfully ask that he be pardoned
